records.title: Abbey Road
records.blurb: “Abbey Road is the eleventh studio album by the English rock band the Beatles, released on 26 September 1969, by Apple Records.” – Wikipedia. This album contains perhaps my favorite Beatles song, “Octopus’s Garden,” plus tons of other wonderful classic tunes I adore.

records.title: Anthem of the Peaceful Army
records.blurb: Greta Van Fleet’s debut studio album dropped in October of 2018. I discovered the band a few months later. As an angsty teenager who listened to a lot of metal and rap, this hippie band brought me positive energy that I hadn’t experienced before from music. Although infused with some cheesy 60s/70s cliches, my 15-year-old self immediately fell in love with all the tunes on this album – and I still stand by that. My favorites include “Lover, Leaver (Taker, Believer),” “The New Day,” and “Mountain of the Sun.”

records.title: The Beatles (White Album)
records.blurb: “The Beatles, commonly referred to as the White Album, is the ninth studio album and only double album by the English rock band the Beatles, released on 22 November 1968.” – Wikipedia. It’s a classic for a reason. My favorites off this vinyl are “Back in the U.S.S.R.,” “I Will,” and of course “Blackbird.”

records.title: Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy
records.blurb: “Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy is the ninth studio album by English musician Elton John, released on 23 May 1975 by DJM Records in the UK and MCA Records in the US.” – Wikipedia. I adore Elton John, and especially this album cover. This is a lovely vinyl that I enjoy putting on while I cook or just lounge around. My favorite song off this one is the title track!

records.title: The Clancy Brothers Greatest Hits
records.blurb: “The Clancy Brothers' Greatest Hits is an original studio album of some of The Clancy Brothers' most popular hits re-recorded with Louis Killen.” – Wikipedia. Professor Raoul Hernandez gifted me this lively Irish folk album because of my experience studying abroad in Ireland.

records.title: Deja Vu
records.blurb: When Professor Hernandez reached into his box of records and handed me this album, I couldn’t have been happier! Déjà Vu, is the second studio album by American folk rock group Crosby, Stills & Nash. The gorgeous, weathered cover opens up to an equally special inside-spread. This is one of my favorite albums, and certainly one of the best vinyls in my collection.

records.title: From the Fires
records.blurb: The first Greta Van Fleet song I ever heard was “Black Smoke Rising” off this EP. Josh Kizska’s vocals instantly entrapped me, like Robert Plant but with a grit and intonation unique to Kizska. This album released on November 10 (my birthday) of 2017. My favorite songs off this EP include “Flower Power,” “Talk on the Street,” and “Edge of Darkness,” all of which I learned to play on guitar in high school. I also love the cover of “Change is Gonna Come.”

records.title: Goodbye Yellow Brick Road
records.blurb: “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road is the seventh studio album by English singer, pianist, and composer Elton John. A double album, it was released on 5 October 1973, by DJM Records.” – Wikipedia. This record is full of classic Elton hits like “Candle in the Wind,” “Benny and the Jets,” and “Saturday Night’s Alright for Fighting.” Who doesn’t love to sing and dance along to some Elton John?

records.title: The Great Buddy Holly
records.blurb: “Originally released in April 1958 as That'll Be the Day, The Great Buddy Holly boasts the landmark Holly hit, as well as nine other tracks of lesser import, notably "Modern Don Juan" and "Rock Around with Ollie Vee."” – Wikipedia. I bought this vinyl at Rough Trade in New York City because I hadn’t really listened to Buddy Holly before despite all I’d heard about his history and influence.

records.title: Macalla
records.blurb: “Macalla is an album by the Irish folk group Clannad released on October 14, 1985. It is their ninth album and is known for the duet between Clannad's singer Moya Brennan and U2 vocalist Bono on the single "In a Lifetime".” – Wikipedia. This is another gift from Professor Raoul Hernandez because I told him about my experience studying abroad in Ireland for a Maymester. The opening chants of Caislean Oir caught me by surprise and immediately captured me in the whimsical vibes of this experimental 80s album. My favorite songs off Macalla include “Closer to Your Heart” and “Journey’s End”.

records.title: Mean Business
records.blurb: “Mean Business is the second and final studio album by The Firm, released by Atlantic Records on 3 February 1986. The Firm were a British rock supergroup formed in 1984, featuring singer Paul Rodgers, guitarist Jimmy Page, drummer Chris Slade, and bassist Tony Franklin.” – Wikipedia. Professor Hernandez gave me this vinyl because of my love for Led Zeppelin. I love “All the King’s Horses” and the simmering heat of “Cadillac.”

records.title: Metallica (Black Album)
records.blurb: “Metallica is the fifth studio album by American heavy metal band Metallica. It was released on August 12, 1991, by Elektra Records.” – Wikipedia. I became obsessed with Metallica in middle school when I dove headlong into classic rock and metal. The Black Album is full of some of their biggest hits and my favorite songs, like “Enter Sandman, “Wherever I May Roam,” “Sad But True,” and “The Unforgiven.”

records.title: Otis Redding Live in Europe
records.blurb: “Live in Europe is a live album by the soul singer Otis Redding. It was Redding's first live album as well as the only live album released during his lifetime, issued exactly five months before his death on December 10, 1967.” – Wikipedia. I adore Otis Redding’s work, and this live album is no exception.

records.title: Planet Waves
records.blurb: “Planet Waves is the fourteenth studio album by American singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, released on January 17, 1974, by Asylum Records in the United States and Island Records in the United Kingdom.” – Wikipedia. My freshman year roommate in the Kinsolving Dormitories gifted me this vinyl. I love Bob Dylan, and this is a funky album with a boisterously gritty sound that especially grew on me after a second spin.

records.title: Poet’s Heart
records.blurb: Poet’s Heart by Kate Wolf is a lovely folk album released on July 1, 1985. Music Journalism professor Raoul Hernandez bestowed this beautiful vinyl upon me after I expressed my love for Joan Baez. I too quickly fell for Wolf’s enchanting melodies and the ever so delicate twang to her voice and her guitar.

records.title: Queen Greatest Hits II
records.blurb: “Greatest Hits II is a compilation album by the British rock band Queen, released on 28 October 1991. The album consisted of Queen's biggest hits between 1981 and 1991, from the UK chart-topper "Under Pressure" to "The Show Must Go On".” – Wikipedia. Although it’s always hard to choose, I think my favorite on this vinyl may be “Hammer to Fall.”

records.title: Starcatcher
records.blurb: “Starcatcher is the third studio album by American rock band Greta Van Fleet. It was released on July 21, 2023, through Lava and Republic Records. The album debuted at number 8 on the US Billboard 200 selling 46,000 album-equivalent units in its first week.” – Wikipedia. I had waited YEARS for this album to drop (ok, maybe like two years I guess since the release of The Battle at Garden’s Gate). On the eve of its release, I lit the Josh Kiszka candle that Ayesha bought me and prepared to be blown away. It did not disappoint! Although I do think the quality of the production on this album could have been better, I believe it has some of the best songs GVF has ever written. From “Sacred the Thread” to “The Indigo Streak” to “The Archer” and “Meeting the Master,” the grandiose and fantastical aura of this album is unlike any other.

records.title: That’s the Way of the World
records.blurb: “That's the Way of the World is the sixth studio album by American band Earth, Wind & Fire, released on March 3, 1975, by Columbia Records. This was also the soundtrack for a 1975 motion picture of the same name.[4][5] The album rose to No. 1 on both the Billboard 200 and Top Soul Albums charts.” – Wikipedia. I also bought this vinyl at Rough Trade in New York City – an original copy from 1975!

records.title: Warp Riders
records.blurb: “Warp Riders is the third studio album by American heavy metal band the Sword. Recorded at Wire Recording in Austin, Texas with producer Matt Bayles, it was released by Kemado Records in August 2010.” – Wikipedia. Although a couple of great songs by The Sword had popped into my Spotify recommendations a few times before, I didn’t truly consider myself a fan until I saw them live a few weeks ago. My dad came to visit me in Austin, and I scoured the Austin Chronicle Calendar to find something fun to do. Of course, I came across a blurb written by Professor Hernandez. The Sword would be performing at the record store End of an Ear – and all you had to do to secure tickets was buy a copy of the re-released Warp Riders. Dad and I drove to End of an Ear for Record Store Day, did some shopping, and snagged ourselves some vinyls as well as two tickets to the intimate show! The group was absolutely locked-in rhythmically, making every riff hit with toughness and precision.
